paragraphs.name: 6edd
paragraphs.text: For example, on voice you can either stick to a defined set of commands for asking questions and thus the users must have heavy training, or you can learn from past queries and intelligently adapt the system to look up information and deliver results. You might want to ask, “What is the Q3 sales forecast for the central region?” or “Who is the budget holder on our Dupont sales campaign?” or “Please list all of my teammates who have had communications with Verizon in the past 90 days.”

b398ba2a5968.title: Enterprise is still woefully behind any decent technology stack.

paragraphs.text: Enterprise is still woefully behind any decent technology stack. This investment sounds very much about the people, who undoubtedly have a rolodex of buyers from their collective time at Salesforce and Oracle. That’s why it’s hard for me to get excited about 22 year-old founders of enterprise startups: they need 6 figures to hire someone with a rolodex just to get started.

Thanks for the inspiration. Definitely employees deserve users oriented applications. There must be a way to manage security requirements releasing employees suffering. Enterprises could unblock so much employee happiness and for sure revenue associated to that!
paragraphs.name: 6d5b

paragraphs.text: I fully subscribe to your thoughts on the emergence of new kind of enterprise software — layered on voice, intelligent data driven decision making, virtual assistant, collaboration and mobile first. Best of luck!

86bb53bb313c.title: Congratulations on leading Tact funding round.

paragraphs.text: Congratulations on leading Tact funding round. Always good to work with someone you’ve already established a solid network alliance like Chuck Ganapathi. Tact seems to have a great team and a product that will push the convenience envelope. Enterprise Software adapted to mobile seems like a no brainer. Glad Tact moved it forward.

a0617f3f2c88.title: As selling SaaS to business, our “wet dream” has been since the beginning to be focused on the user…

paragraphs.text: As selling SaaS to business, our “wet dream” has been since the beginning to be focused on the user. However, we quickly learnt that the buyer doesn’t always want to ease the work of the user, they want things their way (argument heard: “that’s hy we pay them for: work, not play”) so we had to go back to the drawing board and adapting the software to…

a1db6f7830f2.title: Mark Suster thank you for this deep post.

paragraphs.text: Mark Suster thank you for this deep post. My #1 reason for joining Tact this Fall was the team was not just talking about great enterprise user experiences, it was *actually* building them, one heavy Lego block at a time. As a former UX/product guy turned product marketer, I was inspired at Chuck’s superpowers on product and Trevor’s boldness towards…

paragraphs.text: The jury is out on user-centric design moving the needle in enterprise.
paragraphs.name: bf10

paragraphs.text: I personally think it’s worth designing from the user’s perspective simply because it makes a better product, but that’s despite all demands from the buyer to add features that compete with the best user experience.
